fields.headline: Critics' choice
fields.bodyText: The book A Brush With the Past Shirley Hughes Bodley Head, £14.99. Age 7+ In Shirley Hughes's A Brush with the Past, food-related tableaux depict the first half of the 20th century. A relaxed tea in the sunshine of an English country garden in 1914 is followed by a scene showing mugs of tea being drunk in the trenches. In 1950, a cheerful group of young white Americans enjoy ice-cream sundaes, while on the other side of the street a poor black family look on longingly. Alternating spreads laid out to suggest pages from a catalogue, each covering a two-year period, are filled with snippets of social and political information, around the author's conversational account of life at the time. There is much to reflect on, not least the pervading sense that, despite social and political upheavals, people themselves remain unchanged: a seaside picnic is as much fun, a soup kitchen as wretched, today as it was in the 1920s. This is a fascinating book for children and adults. The web Rocks and soils BBC www.bbc.co.uk/schools/4_11/science.shtml Suitable for: KS2 teachers & pupils A wonderful interactive tester lets children examine types of rock to see if they are permeable, will float or split, and how they wear.A quiz will helps the pupils to assimilate their discoveries. Copp CE school www.coppschool.lancsngfl.ac.uk/Classwork/Classwork/Class3/science/science.html Suitable for: KS1 & 2 teachers An introduction to the topic explains how rocks are always beneath us. Brief details about characteristics and uses. Erosion www.windows.ucar.edu/tour/link=/earth/geology/sed_weathering.html Suitable for: KS2 teachers Poor presentation makes this unsuitable for pupils. Useful information for teachers, though, about the long-term effects of weather on rocks. Geography pages www.geographypages.co.uk/limgran.htm Suitable for: KS1 & 2 teachers & pupils Photographs and descriptions of UK granite and limestone landscapes. Murder www.lessonplanspage.com/ScienceSoilTypes.htm Suitable for: KS2 teachers Pupils will enjoy this lesson plan as it involves working in small groups to examine soil samples and decide where a body has been buried. Some previous experience of having looked at soil profiles would be helpful. Oxford University Museum www.oum.ox.ac.uk Suitable for: KS2 teachers Enter the Learning Zone and then the Rock Cycle. The museum has produced a colourful diagram of the rock cycle. There is information about minerals, fossils and some worksheets, including one on granite, limestone, marble and slate. The worksheet is suitable for more able pupils, who will need to fill in the blank letters to complete words. Science Spot http://sciencespot.net/Pages/classearth.html#Anchor6 Suitable for: KS1 & 2 teachers Ride the Rock Cycle is an interesting lesson idea if you plan to cover igneous, metamorphic and sedimentary types. Teacher Resource Exchange http://tre.ngfl.gov.uk/ Suitable for: KS2 teachers Use the search box and enter "soil". "Soil Investigation" is a good set of project materials that includes a lesson plan, guidance notes, worksheet and recording sheet. Pupils will carry out an investigation of soil samples and record findings. Another lesson plan and worksheet can be found under "Sorting Soil". In "Is Soil Just Soil?", pupils record information on a spreadsheet. The CD-rom Mangodata Published by Sherston Age: 6+ Price: £59.95 ex VAT for single user Mangodata enables a whole class to enter data into one database at the same time. The input can be through a table view, or multimedia forms can be created. The data can be searched using simple and complex filters and queries, and presented as a range of graph types. It is suitable for primary and secondary schools. There are four differentiated levels. The teacher can set up individuals, groups and even multi-users over networks and the internet. The program can be used for database work in the QCA ICT scheme of work.
